title: Introduction to Time Management
headline: Learn how to manage your time effectively and efficiently, and minimize distractions in the workplace.
description: This free online time management course will help you become the master of your time. We make big plans, set exciting goals, and look forward to completing them. But then, we just can’t find the time. Managing your time effectively is a key skill that makes your personal and professional life much less stressful. This course will teach you great time management techniques, from work prioritization to mindset adjustment.
courseDescription:
Managing your time effectively and efficiently in the modern workplace is a key skill that all workers need to have. All the demands, distractions and interruptions of the working day can be overwhelming if not managed correctly. The course Introduction to Time Management will offer some suggestions for keeping the tide of external demands at bay and help you to develop a truly efficient routine and rhythm to your working day. Topics covered in this course include the benefits of being organised, how to prioritise your workload and the importance of being in the right state of mind. This course provides time management suggestions which the learner can try out and which can be adapted to fit different work situations. This course will be of great interest to all professionals and workers who feel that better time management skills will help them manage their working day more efficiently and effectively, and help them become more productive.      

Start Course Now

  • The Right State of Mind
  • How do you maintain the concentrated focus required for productive work, in the midst of all the demands and distractions of your working life?
  • Did you know a particular stimulus can trigger a focused concentrated work state?

    Maybe you have a special place you go to for focused work:
    • Particular chair
    • A secluded office
  • Or you may have a favourite: 
    • Notebook
    • Pen
    • Software application
    • Make of computer
  • Sometimes using other tools doesn’t feel quite right. Once you get into the habit of using these triggers, they form a kind of ritual, or process of self-hypnosis if you like.

  • Work with Procrastination 
  • The human psyche seems designed to procrastinate! Some of the key drivers include:
  • The brain is built to firstly minimise danger before maximising rewards
  • Any threat to self is minimised, any handy reward is tempting. This alone accounts for a great deal of our procrastination as we avoid tasks that threaten the self, and we discount future rewards in favour of immediate gratification. A little more focus on emotional intelligence can help here. Too often, feelings trump reasons, and we give into feeling good.
  • Too much uncertainty feels dangerous
  • It feels like possible pain so we avoid it. Task uncertainty is a major correlate of procrastination. It feels dangerous, and we want to avoid this feeling so we do. We procrastinate. The uncertainty in our modern world isn't a lurking predator, but our stone-age brain doesn't know this. We simply feel the potential for disaster. We need to strategically reduce uncertainty rather than just run away.

  • Get It Done Tomorrow
  • The problems created by a never-ending stream of incoming demands. On the one hand, the constant interruptions can destroy the concentration required for productive work. On the other, endless to-do lists create the ‘Sisyphus effect’ - a feeling of hopelessness and demotivation.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • We create a buffer between incoming demands and our response - by making ‘do it tomorrow’ our default response to all requests. Not ‘tomorrow’ as in ‘tomorrow never comes’, but ‘tomorrow’ as in ‘tomorrow’. Not today or the day after tomorrow, but tomorrow.

  • Getting Things Off Your Mind
  • What if you could dedicate fully 100 percent of your attention to whatever was at hand, of your own choosing, with no distraction?

    It’s a condition of working, doing, and being in which the mind is clear… Most people give either more or less attention to things than they deserve, simply because they don’t operate with a “mind like water”.

  • When Should you Review?
  • Review your to-do lists as often as you need to in order to feel on top of things. For example a mini-review every morning when you look through your e-mails and other in-trays (from yesterday of course).

    A larger-scale weekly review is one of the cornerstones of the Getting Things Done system. The weekly review is a time to: Gather and process all your ‘stuff’, Review your system, Update your lists and  Get clean, clear, current and complete

  • When Should you Review?
  • Review your to-do lists as often as you need to in order to feel on top of things. For example a mini-review every morning when you look through your e-mails and other in-trays (from yesterday of course).

    A larger-scale weekly review is one of the cornerstones of the Getting Things Done system. The weekly review is a time to: Gather and process all your ‘stuff’, Review your system, Update your lists and  Get clean, clear, current and complete
  • The main points from this module are:
  • We often get bogged down with all the demands of working life. Tasks seem to snowball out of control until any task seem to become monumental endeavour.

    This Course will suggest ways of keeping the tide of external demands at bay and help you to develop a routine and rhythm that will enable to you make the most of your working day.

    Prioritise work that is ‘important but not urgent’. The way to do this is to work on your own projects first every day, even if it’s only for half an hour. Whatever interruptions come along later, you will at least have the satisfaction of having made some progress towards your own goals. 

    Using a particular stimulus can trigger a concentrated state of mind to work. These can vary from person to person. Some may have a favourite chair or a favourite type of computer or notepad etc. Once you get into the habit of using these triggers, they form a kind of ritual, or process of self-hypnosis.

    To help stimulate triggers you should minimise distractions and interruptions around you in the workplace.

    Interruptions destroy your concentration. If you’re not careful, you can end up in permanent ‘reactive mode’.

    The ‘Sisyphus effect’ is the result of endless to-do lists, which in turn are created by a constant stream of incoming demands.
